review: A nice, casual pool experience with so many options and modes. It's astounding that the developer continues to update the game with fixes and new content after so many years.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039959875', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2770, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 835, 'playtime_at_review': 253, 'last_played': 1712336772}
review:
Hands down the best pool game out there and arguably the best team of developers handling the job at hand. The number of options in the game will blow you away. The ability to tailor the game to your liking is completely unrivalled in the genre. I don't even know how to begin listing the number of things that have surprised me so far.

Do you prefer playing 2D overhead pool or 3D perspective based? Doesn't matter... this game does both. Prefer to play EU pool on a 6ft table with smaller balls over a 7ft table with standard snooker size balls... no problem, two clicks and you're good to go. Wanna go crazy and play 9 ball on a 10ft table with giant balls? Easy. Don't like the look of the balls, no worries, here's another bunch to choose from. Worried about having to set everything up switching between US and EU styles of pool? Well don't worry because the two option sets are separated from each other. Fancy a game of snooker... no problem! Fancy a silly game of snooker on a tiny 8ft table with big balls? Done! Wanna play with a group of friends in the same rule, go ahead! Oh, your friend in 600 miles away in another country just bought the game? Go ahead and play him too... the list just goes on and on and on...

That's without even mentioning the ability to tailor the rules to your liking. Without any learning curve I managed to change the default EU 2-shots rule to be more in line with the current International ruleset.

The only thing missing is the ability to place the ball anywhere on the table after a foul so I asked for it to be added in the community discussions section. Based on what I've seen looking through other posts I'd expect this option to be added by the end of next week!

Which leads me on to the developers...

Just WOW! They respond to their players like no other developer I've ever seen. In one of the most recent 5 posts at the time of looking I saw a guy mentioning a rule he uses in the pub with his friends when playing Killer (an obscure mode also available in this game!) where potting the black ball gives an extra life. The developer agreed it was cool and 4 days later it was patched into the game. Not only that, but the AI was even tuned to prioritise the black ball when possible!!! I've never seen anything like that in my 30 years+ playing computer games.

review: I've played practically every snooker game on the market (e.g. Shooters Pool, Virtual Pool 4, Snooker 19). I love this one. It is the only game to run flawlesly on linux on my aging laptop, it doesn't need to be online to play, and it offers a great experience. The graphics are excellent, the physics seem ok (nothing beats Shooters Pool, but I prefer games where you don't have to cue with the mouse). Love how fast and instant it is to play. Would absolutely love a VR mode for this game - please consider adding it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198011340401', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 12238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1263, 'playtime_at_review': 9921, 'last_played': 1712329250}
review:
I've been playing snooker games since the old Jimmy White's Whirlwind snooker game on pc. But after so many years, I finally found a snooker/pool game that beats it. 

The first thing to mention is the incredible amount of options. Cue's, ballsize, ball-make up, which kind of pockets you want, Size and speed of the table and that just the start. You can make it as hard or as easy as you want it, with no help-lines at all or extensive help and anything inbetween. Switch between 2d & 3d at will, save shots to try again in practice mode, set the number of games to win a tournament at each level, etc etc... .
 
Besides that, it offers a wealth of games, from different kinds of snooker to all kinds of poolgames. As if that wasn't enough, if you feel, like I did that I  made it myself too easy with help-lines and wished I could start again, you can. It let's you do  away with all the steam-achievements (or just the ones you want), so you start at absolute zero.

I'm pretty sure I  listed only half of the options, but it all would mean nothing, if it didn't feel like playing pool or snooker and fortunately, it does. If you like snooker or pool (in my view those 2 are a world apart), get this, recommended at any price.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987843060', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 573, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 525, 'last_played': 1709584087}
review:
Honestly... not quite the best pool/snooker game out there, the physics do seem a step above in virtual pool 4 but that's really where the advantage ends for VP4. The developers of this game are a real credit to the industry in general, every single time there is a concern or tweak the playerbase wants, these guys are there in the forums and take it all onboard and sometimes within hours there will be an update tuning the game and making minor adjustments, ive witnessed this multiple times and im honestly blown away they care as much as they do for a game that obviously is years old now and likely does not continue to sell much at this point, just within a few days of me writing this review ive seen a guy mention in the forums that the killer rules should be updated to reflect uk rules and within hours it was updated, then they updated the sound in a general update to improve ball on ball contact sounds and it seemed a little loud, I mentioned it in the forums and its updated hours later again with improvements, i don't know what more players could ask for from the developers. Updates still drop monthly. Compare that to VP4 which was last updated... what, 2 years ago now, its a different mentality and attitude towards their game entirely.

Visually it looks good but more importantly it performs great, not many games i can play on my steam deck at 4w with 12 hours battery life and 90fps, but this is one of them. Sound wise its fine, there could be more music choice but it is what it is, balls click and clack as expected.

Gameplay wise its very good if not quite perfect (yet), lots of options, different table sizes, different cloths, different balls, different games to play from snooker and pool to variations, 9 ball, 8 ball, killer the list goes on... its missing a career though, some kind of in depth career would be icing on the cake but i suspect that may be too much to ask considering the age of the game right, they would just call it cue club 3 at that point and make more money and im fine with that and i would pay for it.

The ball physics them self are a sticky point for me and many others, they are like 95 percent where they should be but at times you don't get the action you would expect on the cue ball or the speed/weight of the balls seems off, i mean they have options for the speed of everything, cloth speed, ball speed, friction etc etc, the options are endless but you never quite land on what you think feels right, like slow seems too slow but normal feels a bit heavy and there's no in between, so maybe a slider with more minute adjustments would be good but then it becomes a question of why do i need to make the physics feel right when they could do it for me, but i really cant blame the developers, it just feels like it might not ever get there for feel when compared to VP4 perhaps from a limitation of the game engine. Controls can also feel a little off, you either hit the balls too hard or sometimes not hard enough as you try to tame the power and again there are so many options to make adjustments its difficult to know what settings you need for it to feel just perfect (especially on steam deck using track pads). Its like so close but that 5 percent that feels wonky is almost enough to put you off the game while VP4 is just about perfect in how the balls roll and react but the game around it is dead and lifeless in comparison to CC2.

Honestly its hard not to recommend this game, difficult to criticise knowing the love they clearly still have for it. I think there is a really really solid game of pool/snooker here and i cant give the developers enough credit for their attitude towards the game and i hope they have done well enough to start crafting a cue club 3 with a serious career mode and they will have something special in this sport as far as videogames go.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097790912', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 563, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 23, 'playtime_at_review': 295, 'last_played': 1711985350}
review:
This game is very good, overall. Although there are minor things that I don't like, I still enjoy this game.

Pros:
- There are a lot of Pools and Snookers to choose.
- The music is great and relaxing.
- 3D graphics looks good for a pool game.
- Fine control for both controller and mouse.
- Physics is good because I don't have a high demand for it to be as accurate as in real life.

Cons: (These things are minor anyway)
- Menu design somehow is still not well arranged.
- In games vs AI, there is always a notifying panel appearing to inform that cue ball control is passed to the opponent. I accidentally clicked it twice during that panel and the AI was somehow stuck and not made a move. 
=> This should be fixed by replacing with a notification that even AI and I cannot interact. Just a notification and automatic changing turn. That's all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198179774239', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 57640, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 814, 'playtime_at_review': 52266, 'last_played': 1712434191}
review:
Pool and Snooker on your computer.  What else is there to say?

It's a pretty good recreation of the games.  Ball physics seem good, there are all the expected variants of Pool (6, 7, 9 and 10 ball as well as the standard 8-Ball version that every pool table in a pub in the UK has the rules for on a poster).  Snooker also has 10 red and 6 red versions for shorter matches than the proper 15 red version.  

There's some challenge in working your way up through the AIs (15 somewhat distinct AIs, each at 5 different skill levels).  At times the top level AIs will pull off ridiculous shots, but I can't complain too much since very often my tactic is hit the target ball as hard as possible and hope it goes in off five cushions.  There are then extra achievements to try to win four-round tournaments, so there's stuff to keep you playing.

The devs are also active, still releasing updates on a regular schedule and addressing bug reports in the forums.  And there's no subscription or pay-to-win cues for sale in a cash shop.

I got this game probably a couple of years ago now, and I still play regularly.  No complaints here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198977688227', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1700920321}
review:
Wow, what a wonderful game! I hesitated to buy it at first since it was released in 2016 and the price is not cheap. However, after checking out the community and noticing that the developer still cares and updates the game regularly, which is very hard to find with dedicated developers on Steam after a game has been released for so long.

I'm glad I made the right choice. The game does exactly what a good pool/snooker game should do, offering a lot of options. I've already played two games and I already LOVE IT. I can't wait to play online with other human players in the multiplayer mode.

I highly recommend it!!!!!

Update: The developer pushed out another new update on 16/11/23 with even more gameplay options, which are amazing and perfect for playing multiplayer on the same machine, allowing the ability to set different skill levels for each player.

It is a MUST HAVE for all pool/snooker fans.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077879336', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 158354, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2878, 'playtime_at_review': 102939, 'last_played': 1712456330}
review:
Cue Club 2 has very realistic game play against computer characters or humans....
Enter tournaments or play games by yourself, or on a practice table...
Pick your Cue, table size, style of balls, and so much more...
Absolutely a top of the line Pool and Snooker interactive game...
The developers of this game are available for questions in the discussion room which is nice...
Cue Club 2 is a must have for folks interested in playing Pool and having lots of fun.........

author: {'steamid': '76561198127580177', 'num_games_owned': 310, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1833, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1807, 'last_played': 1709672815}
review:
This is currently the best Pool game on the market. The physics are there, the game modes are there and the content is there. As for Snooker, there is one feature missing (in my opinion) stopping it from being the best Snooker game, which is an update which shows cue ball travel after contact with the object ball, because it is so annoying the amount of times the white ball seemingly gets potted for no reason other than my inability to be Ronnie O' Sullivan and predict the path of the cue ball, other than that its perfect. Until that day, possibly (because it still gets frequent updates), then it is a 10/10 for pool and a 9/10 for Snooker, near perfect for what it is. Price and game wise.

EDIT: The wonderful dev team has actually added the feature above. I think this is now the Perfect pool and snooker experience.

review: Typical Pro - Level Difficulty Play:You: Pot a good long last red, then a pink, find yourself making a mistake and not getting good position on the yellow, decide to play safe by putting the yellow against the cushion.AI Turn: Pots the yellow to the far corner and then manages to snooker itself behind the blue, not a problem for the AI.. It can bounce off a cushion and pot a ball.. since that's what all "pro's" do... don't you know.. easy clear up from there... GG..

review: Wow, the Part 2 of Cue Club has returned with great improvements! Well done Bulldog team for resurrecting an old game. I have been a fan of the first version and played a lot during my childhood. I recently came across the new version and must say, it still gives me the same old feeling, even with new features like 3D models, HD graphics, additional tables and customization options. Thanks once again.

developer_response:
Essayez de v√©rifier les fichiers du jeu. Depuis l'application client Steam, faites un clic droit sur la liste Cue Club 2, puis s√©lectionnez "Propri√©t√©s > Fichiers locaux > V√©rifier l'int√©grit√© des fichiers du jeu". V√©rifiez √©galement les mises √† jour du pilote pour votre carte graphique.

Pour plus d'assistance, √©crivez-nous √† support@cueclub.com
-----

Try verifying game files. From the Steam client app, right click on the Cue Club 2 listing, then select 'Properties > Local Files > Verify Integrity of Game Files'. Also check for driver updates for your graphics card.

For more assistance email us at support@cueclub.com

author: {'steamid': '76561198869281511', 'num_games_owned': 2, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 804, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 497, 'last_played': 1694628144}
review: Why am I asked to "buy" what I've already bought?? How could I play for over 8 hours if I didn't already buy it??? Help
developer_response:
Hello,

It sounds like the Steam client interface is asking you to buy again? You could try checking for Steam updates to see if this error can resolve itself. Log out and exit, then log back in.

Also you could write to Steam support and they should be able to solve this for you. Once you buy the game and the transaction has completed, you own it and there is no further purchase required.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978339816', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 196, 'last_played': 1679952202}
review:
Nice things about this game: looks nice (a little bit plasticky and overbloomed though), good graphics, tons of customization.
However, game physics is definitely behind the one in Shooterspool or even Virtual Pool 4: no jump shots, rails do not feel natural, overall feel is somewhat odd. 
If devs would fix physics, the game would benefit dramatically.

Also, it seems there is no way to adjust stroke sensitivity when Cue Control is set to Manual - you either whack it or barely move the cue ball - so there is a huge non-linearity on how mouse movement speed translates to cue movement.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037922005', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 535, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 367, 'last_played': 1677073484}
review: Great pool game, physics are good and nice hd graphics. Have had Virtual Pool 4 for a long time and didn't think I would find a comparable pool game but I was pleasantly surprised by this game. Got it because the devs have kept updating it from it's release a long time ago which  I thought was a good sign and puts them miles ahead of the bunch. Cue controls nicely with mouse or controller and offers 2d and 3d  views. Has tons of different settings for your games. The only thing I would wish for is that the table view would back farther up automatically after the shot. It would have been nice to have straight pool and rotation games added to the list. What a deal on sale, thanks for offering this game.!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198345710431', 'num_games_owned': 512, 'num_reviews': 124, 'playtime_forever': 16, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16, 'last_played': 1675642399}
review: Its a fine game, it just does not seem to add anything extra that you can not already fulfill through a free mobile game. I was hoping for some sort of career driven mode, and though there is a the "bar challenge" it just is a slightly deeper exhibition mode. With that all being said, I had purchased this game on sale for $9.49 and even for that is not worth the price. Maybe the online modes are more stable than other pool games and that is why there is such high reviews, otherwise, if you are looking for a decent, regular ol'standard pool game, this is that and it is way to expensive. Especially for that standard price of nearly $20.

author: {'steamid': '76561198103123687', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 102, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 102, 'last_played': 1675569175}
review: The AI in this game is ridiculous. I'm pretty sure the AI is programmed to score with a pseudo-random probability. It's just that the probability is different under different difficulties. When the AI is programmed to score, it can pocket balls that Ronnie O'Sullivan would never be able to pocket. When it is programmed to not score, it will even miss the easiest shots. Also, the AI has no cue ball control at all. Not recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561198031587838', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 60, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1676528335}
review:
Here for a good pool game?

Found one of the best on steam at a fair price, sale or not, with devs paying attention to their product, so well matured and featured.

Sits at under 125 megs for install, so also an optimized product, so may work on potato PC, and you can refund it, so nothing to lose here.

Noticed they responded to a lot of negative comments, and explained how to do what was OFF to that user.

Graphics and options set all excellent for POOL game!

author: {'steamid': '76561199468416549', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1691, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 902, 'last_played': 1687958903}
review:
I recommend this game because it's easier to play than others, the only niddle i have is that when you
have ball in hand you cannot move the white ball to where you want with a mouse.
developer_response:
Thank you for the favourable review.

To move the cue ball when you have 'ball in hand', place the cursor over the cue ball, click and hold the left mouse button, then drag the ball to the desired spot.

If you have 'Fast Aiming' mode enabled, then place the round aiming target under the cue ball, click and hold LMB and drag the cue ball.

You can also press and hold the 'B' key while moving the mouse.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015145026', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1050, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 107, 'last_played': 1710800690}
review: I have now changed my review to a more positive one. Since all of the updates, this game has become very very playable.  So much so that I am enjoying playing it now. I will recommend this game without hesitation.
developer_response:
Thanks for the feedback.

Have you tried clicking the middle mouse button immediately after the shot is played? Similarly, on a game controller use the left shoulder button. This pulls the camera back further so you can see more of the table action. Also, you can use left and right mouse movement to rotate or pan the camera following a shot (game controller right stick).

In the menu at 'Options > Cameras' make sure you set the the option 'Action Camera (All Players)' to 'Auto Tracking  + Rotation'. This is the default setting and supports the above features.

We will also be making a few tweaks in the next update to further improve the cameras.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044466688', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 1865, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1716, 'last_played': 1706718092}
review:
Really enjoyable snooker/pool game that feels very smooth to use. It works well with both keyboard/mouse or a controller (360 pad in my case) and is a lot of fun. I play with a friend who also has it and it works pretty good once you get used to the delay between someone taking a shot and their opponent finally seeing it play out at their end. Using Steam's remote play option mitigates this if your internet connection and hardware is decent enough to deal with the the stream and the turn-based nature of play means this works pretty well as an alternative if you like to see you opponent (if a Steam friend) play in something closer to real time.

The online lobby has seemed pretty quiet the times we've played so it's probably best to set up a game beforehand with someone if the online play is something you'd like to focus on. 

If solo, there's still loads of game modes and plenty of customisation options to keep you occupied. These along with the smooth gameplay make this a winner for me and it's a lovely change from more hectic games in my library. Nice one Bulldog.

review: only played this for 20 mins so far, I don't normal drop a review so fast, but, had a quick game, but absolutely can see straight away this is the best pool game on the market. controls seem a little strange at first, but make sense, and using a controller is very easy once you've figured it out. Graphics look suberb, better than fx nations. lighting is just right, tons of options for different types of pool and very quick and easy to jump into a quick game when you fancy a quick one. Very stable, so far, imho, smooth running, and well worth the money on the sales which are quite frequent. inexpensive full price too, and I would say if i'd be paying full price I wouldn't be disapointed either. Must buy for anyone who enjoys Pool.

author: {'steamid': '76561198805034039', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 1104, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1689292419}
review:
This game is awesome. I've played 4 hours of it now, but honestly 10 minutes in I could already tell this was immediately SO MUCH BETTER than anything else out there. I've been looking for a great Pool and Snooker game for a while but with limited success. In fact I recently refunded Pool Nation because it turned out they fudged their widescreen support. It's an issue I've seen other games like Pure Pool also struggle with from the discussions I've seen on Steam. This game didn't even have to be told what resolution I was running (2560 x 1080). It just did it from first launch with no glitches. But this widescreen awesomeness was just the beginning!

I LOVE the way the camera works and setting shots up is such an intuitive joy. The tables, balls, cues and scenery all look amazing and one of the things that comes across straight away is how much attention they've put into making all the elements feel right. The cushions repel the balls exactly as you'd expect and the sound is spot on too. The balls themselves roll perfectly and somehow you can tell their weight and how much energy they have from their motion and the sound they make when they strike other objects.

So if you've been wondering if there's a brilliant, fun and well made Pool and Snooker game out there THIS IS THE ONE! :)

review: I bought this game for my dad and me to play over the Internet.    Well it does play, BUT it is always spinning the updating circle and the lag is horrible.   You can't see what the other player is doing in real-time.    We both have High-Speed Internet.   I would give the multiplayer a 1 out of 10.    If you want to play pool online with friends... This is NOT the right one.   KEEP looking.  I wish We didn't waste our time on this game.   It's too bad.   otherwise, the game looks very nice.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984361762', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 538, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 292, 'last_played': 1697044501}
review:
There is not many really good snooker/pool games sadly, so sure it's not like any of these are like big AAA titles for some other sport. What I have played and seen, this is still one of the best ones (maybe even best) snooker/pool game and can recommend for pretty much everyone who wants to play this kind game on PC.

Pros:
* Graphics are good enough and just ok amount of light/effects etc. not to ruin visuals but look good.
* A lot settings, different game modes, rules, etc.
* AI players are good enough, so this is fun to play without multiplayer too
Cons:
* No real career mode feeling, even when Bar games and Tournament modes are a bit like quarter of that
* No player characters really visible anywhere, just non-animated drawn artwork for AI players
* Even when there is multiple settings for rules etc., still missing a lot rules that people seem to use in non official games

Default settings make game a bit too easy probably for anyone who are not totally new to snooker/pool, but there is a lot different settings that makes game difficulty and feel more like what you feel when playing in real life.

[b]Prix d'achat :[/b]
7,19‚Ç¨

[b][u]Prix d'achat conseill√© :[/u][/b]
7,19‚Ç¨

[b]Points positifs :[/b]
[list]
    [*] Nombreuses variantes de jeux de billard
    [*] Personnalisation des tables (taille/couleur de tapis/motif de tapis) selon les jeux
    [*] Effets sonores r√©alistes
[/list]

[b]Points n√©gatifs :[/b]
[list]
    [*] Mode Online totalement d√©sert
    [*] Difficult√© de l'IA mal g√©r√©e
[/list]


[h1]Avis personnel :[/h1]

Apr√®s avoir essay√© de nombreux jeux de billards, et de moins nombreux jeux de snooker, variante du billard que je joue principalement, Cue Club 2 est le 2√®me jeu que je trouve bien r√©alis√©, le 1er √©tant celui qui m'aura fait d√©couvert la discipline il y a une quinzaine d'ann√©es sur PS2. 

De nombreuses variantes sont propos√©es et les ayant toutes test√©es, je peux vous annoncer qu'il y a pas mal de fa√ßons de s'amuser ou d'am√©liorer son style de jeu. J'appr√©cie tout particuli√®rement le snooker comme vous l'aurez sans doute devin√©. Si vous d√©cidez de jouer contre l'IA je peux vous confirmer que tous les niveaux de ce dernier avant le "Professionnel" sont tr√®s mal g√©r√©s, l'IA faisant des coups qui n'ont aucun sens, et qui auront pour cons√©quence de vous faire ais√©ment gagner la partie. En revanche en Professionnel, l'IA est au niveau d'un Ronnie O'Sullivan et ne sera d'aucune piti√©, ne vous laissant parfois pas m√™me jouer un seul coup ! La moindre erreur vous sera fatale si vous avez la main.

Concernant le mode Online, il est totalement d√©sert, le jeu ayant peu de reviews et √©tant sorti il y a plus de 6 ans, c'est tout √† fait logique. Par contre, je ne comprends pas pourquoi ce mode Online comporte des IA contre lesquels on peut gagner des points de ladder. Incompr√©hensible ! 

En conclusion, je recommande ce jeu, si vous voulez vous d√©tendre en frappant quelques billes, surtout que le son des cannes qui frappent les billes, ou celui de ces derni√®res qui s'entrechoquent, sont tr√®s satisfaisants.

Bien √† vous, chers lecteurs !

author: {'steamid': '76561197993621498', 'num_games_owned': 409, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 5113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3638, 'last_played': 1670691486}
review:
At the time of writing, I've just gone over 60 hours playtime with this game. I don't often play games for that length of time, so this alone should tell you, Cue Club 2 is well worth your time.

I'd not long received my Steam Deck, and after trying out many games in my library, I was really in the mood for a pool game, which I didn't yet have. In terms of my history with pool games, I feel like the last time I got majorly into one was Bankshot Billiard 2, on the Xbox 360. I remember playing that game for many hours when it was released on Xbox Live Arcade back in the day. But my all time favourite pool game would be Arcade Pool on the Amiga. And I feel Cue Club 2 shares a lot of what I loved about that game, but in a much more modern package, with many more game types, including snooker. You still have the same top down view, but you can also play in 3D if you prefer. It's as simple as a click of the back button on your controller, to switch between the two views. I prefer to play mostly in the 2D top down view, but I do switch to the 3D view for the occasional long shot, where it does help with aiming, especially the long shots in snooker. 

I've been slowly trying to get all the achievements, which are mostly for beating each game type's tournament on each of the difficulty levels, as well as getting certain breaks in Snooker up to and including a 147, and also scoring so many points in the online mode. I haven't found anyone playing online sadly, but luckily this will not stop you earning the achievements, as there are a couple of bots in the online lobby. So you can still earn those points by playing bots, if you are having trouble finding anyone online to play. It's been great fun working my way through the achievements, and I'm now at 67 of 77, and I still have a good few hours of gameplay left trying to get the remainder. 

The physics for me are excellent. I'm certainly not an expert at pool/snooker in the real world, but the balls react as I would expect them to. You can add spin to the cue ball to curve it round other balls on the table, and it feels great doing this. There is nothing worse than getting a pool game, and the moment you start playing, the physics feeling wrong, so I'm very pleased with the physics here. 

Both pool and snooker play great, and although I was originally looking for a pool game, I've spent a ton of time playing snooker too, and it's brilliant. I'm still working on a 147 break, although I have managed to get the achievement for the 100 break which I'm happy about. 

I don't really have too much more I can say about this game. If you are looking for a pool or snooker game, you really can't go wrong with this one, and with it being a few years old, it won't break your bank either. I picked it up on sale for around ¬£6.50, and got an absolute bargain, but i'd have paid the current full asking price (¬£12.99) if I'd had to. It's well worth that price. 

If you've got this far, just buy the game already.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971366401', 'num_games_owned': 35, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 490, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 438, 'last_played': 1691830947}
review:
Beautifully coded game, perfectly designed. Infinitely re-playable in single player mode.

My only issues are:

1) Loading times. Even on a modern NVMe drive it's still slow to get past the loading screen.
I guess that's because it's so old it's not optimised from modern drive speeds.

2) Lack of online players. That can't be helped, I guess. COME ON FOLKS, GET ON BOARD!

3) Lack of visual effects. Some DoF effects would really make it beautiful. Especially in replays.

4) Cheesy late 90's/early 20's AI character graphics. Could do with a modern refresh. But it's fine.

If you want a pool/snooker sim, THIS IS IT!

author: {'steamid': '76561198165408367', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 1316, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1263, 'last_played': 1702163628}
review:
While i really enjoy this game and have been a cueclub player since the first game in November 2000.. I have one major problem which is very annoying. When you load a tournament save, that save gets deleted on load and should your game crash, you therefore lose any progression in that tournament. Not ideal when playing against PRO level in long matches. Please let us keep saves and let us overwrite them. They do not affect any online play as its all local. I look forward to this becoming a thing.

Updated 30th Jan 2023: Still not implemented and I lost my save on a crash.
developer_response:
Hello,

There is an auto-save feature and so if there is a crash or accidental power-off during a game then you can easily restore the match.

For tournaments, select 'Games > Tournament' from the main menu, then click on the button at the bottom of the screen labelled 'Resume Previous Game'. This will take you back to the last point in the match before the shut down.

From here, you can then select 'Save and Exit' from the in-game menu at any time, if you wish to have a break and resume the match later. The entry will appear in the usual save game slots.

I hope this helps.

author: {'steamid': '76561198162853110', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1726, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1706388043}

Lots of customisation options, offline AI opponents who pose a good challenge and multiplayer, if you can find a match that is, there isn't a huge player base for this game sadly. Really fun and for sure worth the asking price; no DLC nonsense here either.

author: {'steamid': '76561199033808651', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 490, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 279, 'last_played': 1651362761}
review: Its a really fun game with tons of game modes even a short story mode with interesting charecters to faceoff with. The difficutlies feel a bit off like it feells like they could of made expert mode NPC a bit more smart. The online game play out of like 20 matches it feels like every one online is a bot. No one aims there shot online.. No problem to me cause then it comes down to "Ok low rating most likely lower difficutly"  I even tried to use chat to get them to talk like regular people but they only make comments like the bots do in story mode on bad shots you make or tricky shots there in. I love the achievements they look nice not dificult to get overall its a good game if your looking for a fun offline pool game.

review:
Better than Virtual Pool 4 easily.  Likely the best pool/snooker game you can buy on Steam.

Especially impressive is the lack of DLC.  All the table types, all the ball styles, all the pool cues, you get the full game when you buy it.

I was a bit reluctant when I saw how old the game is, but I can't imagine it looking better - in 4k video no less - sounding better, or playing better.  The only thing that 2016 date affects is the price.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977706576', 'num_games_owned': 186, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 169810, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29094, 'last_played': 1670407693}
review:
After 480+ hours playing this game, I have to admit I'm addicted to Cue Club 2.

I have to give the Developers, Bulldog Interactive credit, for their very Pro-Active support of this game.
Constant Upgrades, usually 1 a week, with close attention to customer's wishes.

I had a small 'Visual Bug' after 1 update. It was Sunday in Aust. but I left a post about it anyway. 
That SAME DAY the problem was Acknowledged by Bulldog Interactive.
They had FIXED the problem within 24 Hours !!

I can think of a lot of Developers who could take a page out of Bulldog Interactive's book, can't you?

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198075149760', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 23799, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 74, 'playtime_at_review': 3653, 'last_played': 1712215040}
review:
Note: I've only played bar challenge snooker against the AI (from novice to pro levels, 75 matches in total, using short primary and secondary lines).

Don't let the cheesy cringe-inducing AI opponent artwork put you off. This is a fantastic simulation; the physics are excellent.

Complaint:

The snooker AI is disappointing. There are a total of 75 matches to play in the snooker bar challenge. For the first 74 matches the AI never won a single frame (note: I am a decent player using short visual lines, your mileage may vary). 

Only twice in 74 matches did the AI score a break above 20 points (28, 25). I even purposefully on occasions smashed the balls up and missed shots so that the AI could go for it. It refuses to string more than 4-6 balls together. BUT on the very last match (match 75) the AI came alive! Totally took me by surprise with a break of 58 and 45 in the first frame!

Such a shame that the progression up the ranks provides only novice difficulty right up until the final match. I understand that by turning off the secondary line it will make the game much harder, but it doesn't change the fact that the AI difficulty is flat up until the final match.

Conclusion:

The simulation itself is so good that I can only recommend, despite my complaint. And it is still actively being updated by the devs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132242650', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 5177, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 10, 'playtime_at_review': 700, 'last_played': 1712117695}
review: I love the game, however, in the Americas we play with a strict non-slop, call your shot policy.  If you make a shot, you need to call if it will fall in off another ball or if it is not an obvious shot.  I would also like to see a game called "Last pocket" added.  This is an 8 ball game with the 8 ball pocketed in the same pocket the last ball before the 8 ball is made.  It is challenging.
developer_response:
Hi,

Sorry to hear the game fell short of your expectations.

Call shot is available in 8-ball and 10-ball pool, but you must enable it. From the main menu go to 'Options > Rule Variations > US 8-Ball Pool' then tick the box 'Nominate Ball and Pockets'. You set it once and it auto-saves. I hope this helps.

'Last pocket' is something new that we have not heard of before, it's an interesting suggestion.

review: it is similar to playing billiards IRL.  I like the sound effects and the way you can move the angle for different shots.  over all good semi-realistic pool game.  nice to play when i can't go the the pool hall in person.  I don't like lenny, lol.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967368410', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 443, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1709590244}
review:
My first contact with billiards was with Jimmy White Snooker on Amiga 500. Since then I have played a lot of billiard (both virtual and real).
I think Cue Club 2 is the best billiard game I have ever played. 
It has very good controls. I like the fact that you can "lock" the cue (your aim) where you want it and then you can adjust your aim as u like (spins, angles etc). Also it has lots of aim options.
It also has online. 
But I bought it because the developers are constantly update the game. 
Gj devs!

Cons: Very ugly characters artwork. Why?

review:
If you enjoyed Cue Club 1, this one is a similar experience but with more features.
Physics are fun and allow for various kinds of trick shots, there are many game modes and difficulty levels to choose. And quite a lot of customization for the tables, controls and visual helpers.

Give this one a try, it will not disappoint.

author: {'steamid': '76561198175646758', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 143, 'last_played': 1659442231}
review:
I am but a young man who recently found love for playing 8-Ball Pool and Snooker because my college had a nice pool table. 

It was black with Blue felt.

I can kinda recreate it in this game since it has the ability to style the table a bit. 
Lovely.

I know I can play too at the local pub, but sometimes I just wanna play pool and not go anywhere.

And since I can't afford nor fit a real pool table into my apartment, this game for me is just perfect for when I wanna enjoy a nice game of pool at home alone.

Music is nice and smooth in the background too and the AI is fun to play against.

Big yes from me as a guy who loves real life pool, as this is great to have and very fun to play and relax with at home. 

Physics are pretty accurate as well :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198096258627', 'num_games_owned': 61, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2273, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1547, 'last_played': 1633881214}
review:
Pool/snooker for kids.

Looks very cartoonish, and you're be playing against a monkey, robot, etc.
UI is clunky,
By default the camera always points to opposite direction to what would be logical.
The most difficult pockets to get the ball in that I've ever seen on a pool/snooker game.
Graphics were ok in 2001.
Audience has about 3-4 different reactions.
When you click and choose the color you're about to hit next, it often happens that instead of marking the ball, the click causes you to take the shot..

If you're having a good day, play this to get you angry and to throw your pc into trashbin. 
V1 was a lot better, this isn't worth it even when on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198372377663', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 597, 'last_played': 1652519136}
review: im running a pretty poweful computer on a 48 inch tv with 4k capable of 120 fps although running at 60 fps game starts and i cant see the menus i cant change resolution to try get it to fit my screen and game is totally unplayable as i cant see anything at all looked online for fixes the lot ......uninstalled! i did buy it quite a while ago but had no idea it wouldnt play on any pc i have in future!
developer_response:
Hi, sorry to hear you had this issue. The game can run in 4K. If you want to give it another go, after installation open a file explorer from the desktop and navigate to the EXE file at:
"C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\SteamApps\common\Cue Club 2\cueclub2.exe"

- Right click on the 'cueclub2.exe' file, then click 'Properties'.
- Click on the 'Compatibility' tab, then select 'Change high DPI settings'.
- Tick the box under 'High DPI scaling override', with scaling performed by the application.

Hopefully this will help.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034315837', 'num_games_owned': 7748, 'num_reviews': 765, 'playtime_forever': 914, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 140, 'last_played': 1663825394}
review:
Initial impressions are very strong. The game's physics feel true to life and the game has a lot of ways to play in both single and multiplayer.

Just a quick recommendation to anyone interested in pool especially at this moment before the current sale ends. This game covers all the bases.

Another thing to add the developer seems to be very involved in the steam forum and keeps updating and patching the game. Latest version came out less than a week ago.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043568416', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 26062, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1811, 'last_played': 1678826050}
review:
This is by far the best pool program out there.
You have full control of your shot and you can play any difficulty level you like.
You won't be disappointed.
developer_response:
Hi, sorry you experienced some issues with aiming. We have recently released an update with improvements to make it easier to play curved shots. It might also be worth experimenting with the different cueing methods available.

From the main menu, go to 'Options > Controls > Basic Settings' and switch 'Cue Control' to either automatic or manual, to try them out. I hope something here helps.

author: {'steamid': '76561198111650728', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 94537, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 408, 'playtime_at_review': 13555, 'last_played': 1712452940}
review:
This is the best by far pool game out there! Highly recommend picking this up! This game is very realistic, great graphics, music, and has many games to choose from! 6 ball, 7 ball, 8 ball, 9 ball, 10 ball, Snooker, and killer pool! 5 different difficulty levels ranging from novice to pro, and pro is extremely hard to master. I have played 215 hours on this game and have won all the trophies except for the 147 break on snooker and the multiplayer badge where you have to get to 1000 points by just playing games in multiplayer mode for a 5 star rating.

Suggestions for improvement: Have some additional in game music. I like the tracks but wish there were a couple new ones added. 
For multiplayer mode, after completing a match, have it return to the multiplayer screen rather than the main menu. Have an option to rematch against the opponent after completing a match.

author: {'steamid': '76561198240993000', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 4711, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2475, 'last_played': 1631715182}
review: This game would be fun if the balls behaved ONLY according to physics, and the physics of billiard balls (elastic contact with cloth friction) is decent in this game.  However, your luck depends on your opponent. The last player in the pro tournament (Maya-something) is like no other, an unlike Ronnie O'Sullivan, this pro can pot reds from behind the red's triangle into the baulk end pockets anytime ... when you try to play safe, one of your balls will always be left open for him, and he never leaves anything pots or easy safety shots for you. His luck is too much to be believed.  All the competitors before him at the pro-level are lucky to pot three balls in row.  This lack of realism makes playing the pro-tournament ... less than fun. It's not "challenging" it's just ridiculous.

review: Pretty simple & I would recommend this game, however it's a huge shame that when playing multiplayer, the shots plays for the shooter, and then the other player watches is. It'd be so much better if you could both watch the shots at the same time rather than a replay, a huge stain on what would otherwise be a superb multiplayer game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198274940527', 'num_games_owned': 164, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 4207, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 7, 'playtime_at_review': 488, 'last_played': 1712054904}
review:
On one hand I don't mind this game. The physics are ok, there are lots of game modes to choose from, there are tournaments and single play and the controls are workable. 

The practice table is pretty bad, the controls for setup aren't great and there should be preset practice challenges (like the pros use for practice) where you can practice specific elements of your game (cue ball control around the table, a certain spin, swerve, angles off the cushions etc). You don't even have a setting where you can have the colours replaced (which breaks any chance of creating some rhythm mid practice).

The main reason I can't recommend this game is that the AI on the harder levels are the worlds most unbelievable flukers. You can put them in the hardest spot and they pull out a crazy double or foul but then snooker you (in a gamemode where you don't get a freeball/ball in hand/opponent play again) so you lose a life as well. The odd once in a blue moon fluke is ok (as in the real game) but I have played an AI who has had 3 outlandish flukes in one frame. 

I quite enjoy playing the harder levels outside of this as you can see how to improve your overall game/matchplay skills (you can see the spin and cue angle they are using before their shot). But the harder level games will always be close margins of victory and I can not reward a game where you can work hard and virtually earn a victory against a tough opponent to lose to outrageous flukes.

review: Long time ago, I played Cue Club, I liked it, I was looking for Cue Club in steam, and I found that Cue Club 2 was out, so I tried it, it is almost the same formula that Cue Club has. I like this game because it is simple, the controls are good (I use a keyboard and a mouse), the graphics of the backgrounds and AI players, for me, are ok, not so spectacular, the background music, for me, is ok. Cue club2 allows to adjust the level of difficulty. I like the simplicity of the game. If you are a simple guy like me and like pool games, give this game a try.

review:
Seems like nice game, if anywhere in the game of snooker it actually told one how to nominate a colour then I might have finished a frame.  Not helpful when this git keeps telling me to hurry up while I'm trying to figure it out. I live in hope.

Hope has arrived thanks to help from the developer, I'll go again and update. Originally gave it a thumbs down by mistake which I have corrected.

Got the hang of things now, been playing snooker, nice lounge, nice sounds, very relaxing.
developer_response: Hi, thanks for this feedback. To nominate a colour in snooker, move the round aiming target directly over the ball then click the left mouse button or gamepad A button. I hope this helps.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970830402', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 3700, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 359, 'last_played': 1703080013}
review:
A cross between Team17 Arcade Pool and Jimmy Whites Snooker (the good Archer Mclean one). Much better than the price might lead you to believe, with good levels of difficulty, even if it suffers from the terminal PC cue sport problem that the AI can make some insane shots (respotted black potted with one shot for example). 

If you want a good cue game with a variety of options, go for it. Worth the money and playable in either 2d or 3d with plenty of options.

review:
Muy buen juego , si jugaste el cue club 1 este te va a encantar y como es obvio por tener un numero mas es mejor a cuantos gr√°ficos , sonido ahora podes variar la c√°mara en 2d como el primer juego o 3d eso esta muy bueno la verdad , la m√∫sica y el sonido es una delicia , el multijugador es medio falso porque son maquinas IA las que controlan a las supuestas personas , todos los modos de juego que puedan existir en el pool , lo √∫nico que extra√±o y mucho son las salas para invitar a la IA como tenias en el primer juego donde pod√≠as insultar , elogiar o retar a un jugador y as√≠ ganabas estrellas y cuanto mas estrellas tenias pod√≠as jugar con el due√±o de la sala y luego te daban la tarjeta vip para otras salas de pool era muy divertido eso y es lo que extra√±o , ac√° se perdi√≥ eso , simplemente jugas contra 5 y si les ganas te dan la tarjeta para la otra sala , no tienen ni chat ni gracia jugar as√≠ , es una verdadera lastima que no este eso incluido antes por lo menos te quedabas horas y horas leyendo las boludeces que dec√≠a la IA incluso hasta pod√≠as ver sus partidas ,, por eso le doy un punto negativo y que incluso el cue club 1 no este en steam me rompe las bolas...
7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198025751022', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 11662, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 230, 'last_played': 1706753865}
review:
[h1] Spoiler-free Review [/h1]

Cue Club 2 is an excellent pool and snooker game. I would say the best I've played. The graphics are amazing, and the snazzy jazz/lounge music is really cool. There are many different game modes and play styles, so much so that it actually felt overwhelming at first, in a good way! You can play 6, 7, 8, 9, 10 Ball Pool, Speed Pool, Killer Pool, and Snooker any way you like. There are also great guides that provide detailed instructions on the specifics of each game and how to learn and master them. The value here is excellent.

If you love personalizing your game, then you‚Äôre in for a treat. Almost everything is customizable, including the cues, ball sets, chalk, table (such as the size, cloth, pattern, finish, pockets, etc.), background, effects, lights, colours, music, visuals, cursors, you name it‚Ä¶ Literally everything, and in the moment to moment gameplay, that really makes a difference and greatly adds to realism and immersion. It feels like you're there.

The physics are ultra realistic, the controls are tight and the gameplay is super smooth. Once you get the hang of it, this game can get addicting! The developers are also great and committed to making the game even better with regular updates. All in all, Cue Club 2 has it all and is an impressive pool and snooker game that any fan of the sport would surely not want to miss!

[h1] Score: 10/10 [/h1]

review: After the series of updates, the game is ruined. I spent 10 minutes in Settings and still don't know how to shoot a ball. Before I played 79 hours in this game. Bad work, guys.
developer_response: Hi, we're sorry to hear you've had these issues. A recent addition was the 'Fast Aiming' control method. You could try turning that off, if you prefer the previous control system. Go to 'Options > Controls > Basic Settings' and set Fast Aiming to Off. Also try toggling the 'Cue Control' option between Manual or Automatic. Hopefully this will help, but feel free to contact us at support@cueclub.com if you need further assistance. Thanks.

author: {'steamid': '76561198394158855', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 30134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 347, 'playtime_at_review': 766, 'last_played': 1712436185}
review:
I have probably spent a few hundred hours playing its predecessor Cue Club, but that was almost 15 years ago and that too on a CRT monitor. 
I only got like 12 hours here so far but so far it has been quite nice. 
A brief comparison vis-a-vis its predecessor is present below for reference.
Better in Cue Club 2 - Game dynamics, game types, improved graphics, multiplayer, music
Better in Cue Club (older)  - Cue and ball varieties,  Bar system, smoke on the table 

I think I will give the older one a go if I can find my iso collection. Hopefully it will run in compatibility mode.
______________________________________________________________________
Major negative thing that I missed out in the original review (posting on 24 July 2020):
1. AI freeze is quite regular. Balls won't get placed back on table, AI opponent may not play at their turn.
2. GUI freeze is also quite common. After a ball is pocketed, the control panel won't show up again. The button to switch between the top control panel views is greyed out.
3.  Speed pool experience is badly hampered by ball dropping into pockets animation. May be the control to disable the control panel view switching is somewhere, at present I am unable to find it. The window reverts too late for me to figure out when can I play my next shot.
________________________________________________________________________

Updated on 25 July 2020 - Changed review to negative as game has regular issues
Game GUI/AI froze once again while playing 10 Red Snooker Tournament. Option to 'save and exit' was also greyed out so basically my whole progress is gone. In case any developers are paying attention to issues, please find below the sequence of events:
1. Pink ball was potted and wasn't placed back even though red balls were still there on table.
2. After missing on the next red, AI opponent took one shot where white ball was not present even though the whole animation was played.
3. Despite no red ball being potted, it still shows as the AI opponent's turn again.
4. Switching between windows and other gimmicks  with visual settings didn't get it back.
___________________________________________________________________

Final review update: Changed to positive recommendation following prompt help from Cue Club support team. I will add the workaround method on the forum so that it can be used by all players till the formal fix is issued as part of the next release.

Revised review ( 05 June 2022) - This game gets changed too often and some of these changes affect the ball dynamics.  I no longer find the ball dynamics consistent enough for me to like this game.  The weird ball movement is very frustrating considering that these days I only play snooker and that too on medium or low power without spin. The number of times I just Alt+F4 this game in frustration must be in hundreds
developer_response: Hello, and sorry to hear you've had this issue. Please can you email any related screenshots to support@cueclub.com and we'll investigate to help find a fix. Thank you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989728902', 'num_games_owned': 620, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 1120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1089, 'last_played': 1675191423}
review: In my opinion, the first Cue Club was better. Some things, modes and mechanics are changed/upgraded in CC2 but music in CC1 was way better for my taste. Now you can switch between 2d and 3d view and every mode, cue and room is unlocked from the beginning. I preferred to unlock rooms on my own and to chat with bots but times has changed. Cue Club 2 is great as it's the only available version. I miss the first Cue Club, still recommending this sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088990608', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 7265, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5354, 'last_played': 1700552841}
review:
I you like shooting Pool or Billiards, you liked the first game, or just need a skills based game to kill some time...
THIS IS THE ONE FOR YOU.
These guys update constantly, they bring good, useful features, and they have the best simulation you could ask for. Complete customization, or just wing it. Varying AI, just all around fun. This is like my Hot Shots Golf on Play Station, but on PC.

A DEFINITE RECOMMEND, YOU WILL NOT BE DISAPPOINTED.

author: {'steamid': '76561198214280533', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 1699, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 80, 'last_played': 1616216172}
review: I like how detailed the graphics are in the game, especially the balls. Although I'm more of an 8 ball person, I also like that there'a variety of pool games which include not only 9 ball or snooker, but also lesser known games such as 10 ball. The new update where all 15 computer opponents can be played from novice to professional has especially made this game even better! However, I just have a problem with the AI difficulty in snooker and Euro 8 ball (I don't know about all the other pool games except 8 ball as I never tried them) as in intermediate, they're too easy to beat as they can't even sink balls that are in close and easy angles but then in expert, they're too hard to beat as they use strategy and spin to beat me. I don't know if this is just me or not, as I'm not an expert pool player myself. I just figured I'd point it out. Overall great game otherwise, especially when you play with your friends.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970701598', 'num_games_owned': 94, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 316, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 203, 'last_played': 1628186733}
review: Een erg leuk spel voor al diegene die van biljarten houden. Je kan eerst genoeg oefenen op diverse tafels en uiteindelijk diverse wedstrijden gaan spelen, waarbij je de camera van bovenaf, maar ook van achter de bal kan positioneren. Zeer uitdagend met duidelijke verbeteringen t.o.v. Cue Club 1, jaren geleden.

So many annoying bugs, especially after those updates. After the latest one those trophies disappeared and needed to be obtained once more. Sometimes the balls would stop and stick with each other (I feel sorry for Newton). Sometimes the aim-assisting line disappears.  Besides, the trace of my saved shots got disrupted when I played the game on different computers with different screen resolutions. Plus sometimes I can't even replay some of the saved shots and I can't even find my fucking mouse and delete the stuck shots. Nice game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022968650', 'num_games_owned': 198, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1023, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 197, 'last_played': 1593692363}
review: I don't think I've played a Snooker/Pool game since Archer Macleans JWS on the Commodore Amiga. I loved that game and Cue Club 2 does a good job of it too. Looks good. Play's well. Plenty of Game versions to try depending on what rules you know. If you like the real thing you will go well with this.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972398628', 'num_games_owned': 353, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 3050, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1210, 'last_played': 1593805727}
review: I really rate Cue Club 2 as a pool sim. Having spent hours and hours playing the original, so much so the CD became badly scratched and would load any more. Years (decade) later I suddenly the sequel on Steam. What's more it was in the sale, so I immediately purchased and downloaded it. Just as good as I remember, great controls and physics, frustrating tournaments but well worth the effort!

author: {'steamid': '76561197992997168', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 798, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 382, 'last_played': 1598467270}
review: I like the physics, it feels very true . At no point was I upset with the ball on ball contact and behaviour of the table cushions. The AI opponents are a good gradual challenge which encourage you to improve and get tougher as you progress. The light indicators are a small cheat, but compensate well for the lack of tactile feel and 3d perspective of a real pool table. I havent played online yet so cant comment on that.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991708280', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 3179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 178, 'last_played': 1630541172}
review:
A superb pool game.

AI is good on later levels and represents a worthy but not artificially unbeatable challenge.
Graphics are very good but most of all the physics and ballistics just feel 'right'.
Loads of single player game options (European and American etc), as well as Multiplayer on same PC and online as well if you want (although I haven't tried that yet).

I play a lot of pool myself and this is as close as I've come to playing a true digital representation and I own pretty much all of them. Not been this impressed with a PC pool/snooker game since I first played Archer McLeans's superb Jimmy Whites eon's ago.

Two gripes though - 

1 - Most importantly. Intermittently, the back spin doesn't take effect which can be frustrating on a big break or in a tournament situation.

2 - Waking away from the game or not playing for a a while can lead to the game freezing. This loses your progress in a tournament if you haven't saved.

 

Other than the above, wholeheartedly recommended.

review: Cue Club 2 is a disappointing pool sim that can‚Äôt compete with the ones on my mobile phone. It‚Äôs annoying and immersion-breaking to see the computer AI use the mouse pointer and game menus like a human player. The game also lacks the option to change the screen resolution in-game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198301878125', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 202, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1584084217}
review: I would like to recommend this game. The Bulldog Interactive keeps updating this game to become a perfect one. The game is easy to learn to play. The game-play is quite smooth. The music is comforting. I would recommend you playing this game when you are tired. It can really help you relax. You can also compete with others online. There are also puzzles and challenges for you to figure out solutions. I have once played Snooker 19 on Epic, but to be honest, the game design in that game is quite challenging. I think the design of this game is really impressive and suitable for mass players. Pool & Snooker are really dynamic and lively. Keep up with the good work and listen to players' advice. Well done!

author: {'steamid': '76561199020906572', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2323, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 626, 'last_played': 1694970059}
review: Excellent HD graphics and physics. This game also has full support for whichever controller you prefer - mouse, trackball, or gamepad. I personally use a trackball and had no issues setting up or taking shots. Although the game allows you take shots by pushing forward with a mouse, It also allows an option to shoot with the click of a button.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051517179', 'num_games_owned': 2832, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 418, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 182, 'last_played': 1675699045}
review:
Great Pool game. I have one other Pool game in my library - which WAS also good (had the potential to be great) - but was abandoned by the developer (which released a second game WAY too soon to win my support again). This game however, the developers are supporting their product and still actively engage with the community regarding features and bugs/glitches.

I can definitely recommend this great game. (I have not tried playing against human opponents in online games - but I am really enjoying the Bar Championship)

review: Das beste Pool. Hatte erst die gro√üen, also Pool Nation, Pool Nation FX und Pure Pool. So sch√∂n Pure Pool auch aussieht... das Men√º ist... hat das von den Entwicklern mal einer √ºberpr√ºft? Nation FX sieht irgendwie nicht so gut aus. Und Nation ist zwar optisch ne Augenweite, aber dieser "Zwang" zu besonders Actionreichen St√∂√üen nervt auf dauer gewaltig. Und dann kommt dieses kleine Cue Club daher. Tischgr√∂√üe anpassbar! Das ist Soooo ein gro√üer Punkt. Das selbe Spiel spielt sich auf einem 6er gaaanz anders als auf nem 9ner.  Die Regeln sind anpassbar. 2D und 3D in einem, beides wird auch heute noch st√§ndig mit Patches verbessert. Alles ist irgendwie einstellbar. Und das Spiel braucht keine Mausakrobatik, man w√§hlt vorm Sto√ü alles genauestens aus. Es ist einfach die Bombe unter den Billiardspielen. Selbst Snooker ist enthalten. Alle anderen Spiele hab ich deinstalliert. Au√üer Poolians Billiard 3d. Einfach weil ich auch gerne mal einfach nur Zuschaue. :) Von mir gaaaanz klare Kaufempfehlung, das Beste Billiard weit und breit, nur mit leichten grafischen Abstrichen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198326433399', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2306, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1502, 'last_played': 1702673852}
review: Cue Club 2 and Virtual Pool 4 are my favorite titles for Billiards.  Both titles have some very strong positives. I like the many options in Cue Club 2. I am also very impressed that the developers continue to update the game for players. I would like to see the removal of the cartoon style players. The women need to be dressed in a more modest way for the younger players of the game. Playing against an Ape and a Robot really takes away from the experience.  The many table options and rooms are a real positive.  I would like to see some additional ball designs in the future.  I again praise the developers for their continued support of this great title!

author: {'steamid': '76561198428624159', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1077, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 766, 'last_played': 1698516906}
review:
It's a good arcade pool game, great to pass the time and knock a few balls around, however, there's still room for improvements, like adding 14.1 continuous (Straight Pool) or even carom billiards, adding more locations, snooker cues, jump shots, having the option to play 'race to...' frames not just 'best of'. There's also some bugs like when using the aiming aid and a few more. The 3D camera should be more flexible and not fixed close to the cue ball, it's difficult to aim in 3D sometimes. It would be great to skip the AI shots too. The physics are questionable at times.

EDIT 1: I have encountered a bug in which a potted ball is the 'on' ball, it's fixed by restarting the match. 
EDIT 2: It crashed when I enabled the music, the game had started on mute.
EDIT 3: The pocket/jaw physics are abysmal, if it's not straight in, it's a miss! Please fix them!

author: {'steamid': '76561198101446609', 'num_games_owned': 1796, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 9977, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 14, 'playtime_at_review': 3721, 'last_played': 1711305850}
review:
Sin duda el mejor juego para quienes aman el pool y/o el snooker
En cuanto a la jugabilidad no tengo quejas esta muy pulido y presenta una amplia cantidad de modos de juego que desprenden del pool y el snooker, con las reglas reales de juego muy bien definidas y con la posibilidad de personalizar algunas de estas. Ademas se actualiza constantemente, los desarrolladores estan pendientes del juego.
Muy recomendado sin nesesidad de esperar a las ofertas para comprarlo, vale la pena el precio, lo √∫nico malo es que no hay mucha gente en el multijugador pero es de esperarse en este tipo de juegos.

Eso si, si alguno es obsesivo con los logros, amenos que sea un experto en el snooker no compre el juego o va a sufrir mucho con el Break 147 se lo puedo asegurar.

author: {'steamid': '76561198152760885', 'num_games_owned': 17519, 'num_reviews': 481, 'playtime_forever': 531, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 531, 'last_played': 1533239243}
review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
This shall be my second review for a simulation of cue sports. Colloquially refered to as ‚Äúbilliards‚Äù, we can all agree that it‚Äôs an activity which still poses great interest even after more than five centuries since its invention. There may be at least a dozen online alternatives to Cue Club 2, yet few offer as much customization as the title I‚Äôm reviewing today. It is Bulldog Interactive‚Äôs Steam debut and their project has certainly improved substantially over time. You might be wandering about Cue Club 1 at this point. This particular developer has focused on cue sport simulations since 2000, which is almost as long as I‚Äôve been gaming on PC. Cue Club 2 saw an initial retail release in 2014 and it has graced the Steam Store since 2016. If you‚Äôre good at something, never stop improving it. Or do it for free, since I‚Äôm certain that you‚Äôve stumbled across plenty of F2Ps featuring billiards and snooker. They were rather thin on content, am I right?

[h1]Story[/h1]
Now, I could bore you with more historical details about cue sports, but I shall obviously avoid that path. Cue Club 2 has no story mode per se, yet the Bar Challenge can be considered a solo campaign designed specifically for players which do not wish to sink their teeth too deep into multiplayer that's ranging from championships to casual matches. Before discussing the Challenge, let me share my own experience with billiard simulations. Long before I enjoyed the activity in real life, I developed a taste for it in it‚Äôs digital format on PCs. There may have been several self-standing games based on pool, which I played earlier to some extent but quite surprisingly, it would be the Grand Theft Auto series (San Andreas, precisely) which managed to prove how fun and lucrative this activity can be. A visit to the Ten Green Bottles would both relax and allow for a friendly wager (crucial funds during a fresh start).

The sheer versatility of cue sports cemented their reputation as a favorite pastime of both blue and white collars. From watering holes in the middle of nowhere to pretentious social clubs, billiards receive the appreciation they deserve. Cue Club 2‚Äôs Bar Challenge is divided into three sections of gradually increasing difficulty: Basement, Cocktail and Penthouse. Three bars filled to the brim with worthy opponents. We get the usual assortment of skilled female and male players, but also more exotic rivals such a talented ape and a robot. Let no one claim that pool titles can‚Äôt mix some humor into the already established formula. In fact, the AI of your opponents will ensure that the Bar Challenge lives up to its name. It won‚Äôt be easy and it proves to be the perfect tutorial/warm up for the subsequent modes. As good a replacement for a story as you could hope for, given the gameplay. No cheesy cutscenes in Cue Club 2.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
I couldn‚Äôt find any information about the graphics engine, so we‚Äôll proceed with the default assumption that it is proprietary to the developer. A hybrid 2D/3D perspective is a feature that we‚Äôve all come to expect from contemporary cue sports simulations. Cue Club 2 does not disappoint on this front whatsoever. Depending on your preferences, you can enjoy the game in either 2D top-down view or fully rendered in 3D and far closer to the real life experience. I‚Äôm obviously a fan of the latter, since the former can make the game somewhat easier than intended. We‚Äôre not cheating on the Bar Challenge, fellas. Speaking of which, ball trajectory estimations will fully cater to new players. You don‚Äôt have to fear being left completely helpless, if your pool skills are rusty or non-existent.

As far as performance was concerned, I have no complaints. Everything scaled perfectly to 4K resolution and the frame rate never dropped below 60fps at any given moment. The aforementioned rich customization options come into play during the breaks between matches (not during ongoing championships though). I strongly suggest you fiddle with the settings menu and discover for yourselves, exactly how much you can tweak the experience. From changing the appearance of tables, cues and ball sets, to modifying the rules which shall govern the matches and ultimately ensure or hinder victory. European Pool doesn‚Äôt have to be much more complicated than the streamlined American version, which is also my personal favorite. Don‚Äôt even get me started about Snooker!

[h1]Audio[/h1]
Indeed, there‚Äôs no voice acting in Cue Club 2 but the soundtrack manages to compensate that, while text boxes represent the only interaction between players and the rivals you‚Äôll have to defeat during your playthrough. Song diversity is balanced. It never got too close to repetitiveness since I was more focused on the game than on the sounds. You can always opt for listening to your own tracks of choice, so no cause of concern over acoustical inadequacies.

 [h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The bread and butter of any cue sport simulation will always be represented by the versatility of its various modes. It would have been far too simplistic to slap a US, Euro or Snooker label and call it a day. Bulldog Interactive offers some much needed variations: Killer Pool, Red Snooker and the ‚Äúrapid fire‚Äù 6 Ball Pool which I compare to Blitz Chess in terms of duration and challenge. The standard pool game on both sides of the Atlantic, contains 15 balls (stripes and solids/spots) and a cue ball that‚Äôs usually blank or featuring a dot pattern. Snooker on the other hand, uses 22 colored balls along with a cue ball and can drag on for longer than I‚Äôm comfortable with. It‚Äôs always a matter of preference and Cue Club 2 offers either the standard or tailored versions which may speed up the process to a certain extent. Cutting corners quite literally, since table customization enables several pocket designs.

One key aspect I always seek out when analyzing cue sport simulations, is the Artificial Intelligence‚Äôs capabilities even on lower difficulty settings. Multiplayer matches and human minds are more difficult to predict and mistakes are rarely made on a consistent basis if you‚Äôre playing with someone skilled enough. How about the AI in a pool game? I judge their competence or the lack thereof, by observing the involuntary early pocketing of the 8-ball. That is the ‚Äúcardinal sin‚Äù of any cue sport afterall. It spells ‚Äúgame over‚Äù and an easy, albeit somewhat undeserved victory for an opponent that might have fared badly in terms of pocketed balls. Out of turn pocketing is more lenient for stripes & solids but not for the ‚Äúdreaded‚Äù eight-ball. Cue Club 2 surprised me by how rarely would the AI commit such an error. The Bar Challenge proved to be a worthy experience and I had my share of defeats against an AI which calculated both the approach angle and strike strength with alarming alacrity. 

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
Overall, Cue Club 2 distances itself from its competition by giving players some much needed freedom for the rule sets as well. Custom profiles that transcend mere chromatic choices, offer flexibility to an otherwise rigid sport and pastime activity. It was only natural to allow billiards their chance of adapting to the audience, since the real life version has managed that quite admirably. Whether you play pool in a roadside bar or in a downtown club, the game depends on more than just a steady hand and a clear mind. It takes plenty of creativity and patience. Enjoy a cold pint and only pocket the 8-ball at its right time!

 [h1]Strong Points[/h1]
+ Steam Achievements.
+ Adequate challenge scaling.
+ Pleasant graphics and soundtrack.
+ Excellent simulation with replay value.

[h1]Weak Points[/h1]
- Inherent repetitiveness of the gameplay.
- No Steam Trading Cards.

[b]Rating 80/100[/b]

[quote]This review was submitted for [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/ImperialReviews]Imperial Reviews[/url] through the generous contribution of the game‚Äôs developer and the Steam Curator Connect program.[/quote]
